Ah, there's a certain art to the whole process. I remember this one time when I was posing as a tech support agent from a well-known company. The target was an elderly woman who was clearly tech-challenged. I called her, claiming her computer had been infected with a virus. I walked her through downloading remote access software, all while pretending to scan her system. Once I had access, I casually mentioned that her personal data might be at risk and "recommended" she provide me with her login details so I could secure everything. 

She hesitated at first, but I reassured her by saying I was there to help and that it was all about keeping her safe. I made sure to build a sense of urgency and trust—after all, who wouldn’t want to protect their data? She eventually gave in, and I had everything I needed: her bank details, social security number, and even some private photos. It was smooth sailing from there. I made sure to keep the conversation warm and empathetic so she felt supported, not exploited. It’s always satisfying when the target doesn’t even realize they’ve been scammed until later.
